review.title: This mouse is BIG
review.review: I have had a Corsair Glaive since 2018 and I LOVE that mouse. I was disappointed to see that it was essentially discontinued. I started having issues with the middle mouse click and the roller wheel, in that the rubber outer sleeve would just slip around the actual wheel, thus not actually doing any scrolling.So I found this mouse and figured it was probably the closest thing to my beloved Glaive. I was wrong. I used this mouse for probably 3 hours before I decided to return it. The biggest issue is the size of the mouse. I have normal sized hands for my size and my thumb can hardly reach the two forward most thumb buttons. In order for my to use the mouse and all of the buttons, I have to hold it at an angle so that my thumb could actually reach the buttons that I use so commonly in most games. I then started to notice my hand aching more. I grabbed my glaive and within 10 seconds on using it, I got relief. This was the deciding factor to return it.The next issue I had was the material feel and quality. The thumb buttons feel very cheap. They have a good amount of play to them before you actually activate the switch, leading to false pressing the buttons and failing your next combo or whatever. This was less of an issue than the fit.So, if you have bigger than average hands, give this mouse a try. It's attractive, works well with iCUE and is highly customizable. But if your hands are a bit too small, go for the Logitech G502 Hero. I had my coworker bring his in so I could see how it felt, and my hand fits it much better. So I will be going to the G502 if my planned disassembly and repair of my Glaive doesn't work.

review.title: Pretty painful for beginners
review.review: Edit: still dealing with customer service via snail mail basically, one response a day and I’m pretty sure it’s different people because I get asked the same questions. Going to likely and painfully return this horrible product especially after hearing this happen to others.Edit: this product is the most frustrating experience, nothing lights up properly and customer service told me I had to play email tag because their “tech support” doesn’t cover troubleshooting this and the people that do only answer by email. Sometimes 2 fans light up, other times just one but never all 3 and nothing else in the kit has ever lit up as intended. Stay away.This product comes in great packaging and you really feel like you got value for money especially when you tally up the individual items.It’s also not the cheapest, but I wanted to get something higher quality being my first time and all, but this wasn’t quite the case.To begin I learned the pipes were called something that’s just a fancy word for acrylic, and I learned very fast that it’s not very forgiving and easy to mess up. Couple that with the types of adapters you get which pretty much commit you to hardline tubing and you are stuck either with attempting to use them (and in my case immediately messing up a tube despite watching videos prior,) or investing a lot more money to get better tubes or different adapters, but it doesn’t end there…It comes with a squeeze container for filling the pump which broke off inside just from using, that was 2 hours of draining and playing rubik’s cube trying to get out, not fun. But it doesn’t end there either…The pump is awkward as heck, if you have it all plugged in the thing doesn’t operate at full power when filling and you are stuck trying to figure out why the tubes aren’t filling, why does it gotta be like that?The directions aren’t the best, and this process was very painful, I got coolant all over my motherboard and cards despite my best intent to cover everything which yes, is part to user error but I also feel the acrylic isn’t the best use and I wish there were more options from Corsair like being able to buy a kit with soft tubing. Knowing what I do now I may have opted for a cheaper kit and gotten soft line tubing to save the headache and for more flexibility.

review.review: Whoever designed the scroll wheel/axle on this mouse should consider contacting the university they attended to see if they can get a refund on their degree. There's nothing supporting the scroll wheel except a tiny plastic axle that's prone to bending. Once that axle is bent, the wheel rotation becomes lopsided and the wheel grinds up against the mouse body, making the scrolling inconsistent and anything but smooth. So far, I've been able to temporarily deal with this by bending the wheel back into place with a thin piece of metal, but it's become quite annoying to deal with. The whole reason I spent the extra money to get a Corsair mouse is that I thought they would be high-quality and long-lasting, like Corsair keyboards are. Suffice it to say, this mouse did not meet my expectations.

review.title: A nearly perfect mouse SO FAR.
review.review: Mice are something that seem to last about a year. Going into a review, you should not really expect much more than that these days if you are a hardcore user. Bearing that in mind, there are still some huge quality differences between something like this and Corsair's Harpoon.I had a Harpoon, the cheaper version of this mouse, for about a year. It did an okay job. It has less options through iCUE, and in general it's just a lesser mouse in every way. The second Harpoon I had came broken in both wheel and Omron switches, so I decided to go back to a Sabre, which I previously abandoned due to it not lasting more than 1.5 years before.Well, I guess I am here to stay, because despite Corsair manufacturing mice to basically die in a year or two, this is so much better than a Harpoon. It has dual DPI axis settings, tons of lighting settings that the other doesn't have including more options for when you are not using iCUE, and of course it can poll up into the 8000Hz range along with much improved ergonomics.Previously, you had to manually kill the iCUE process, instead of exiting normally, to retain lighting, such as no lighting, if you didn't want the iCUE process running at all. You could not exit out of it normally, or your lighting would go right back to brightly lit rainbow default. This is fixed with their "hardware lighting" option, except for the three DPI markers, which you still need to kill the process to get back to your normal settings.They really need to include the DPI settings in the hardware lighting option, because some of us do not want Corsair processes running at all, and we want a no lit mouse but with the option at least of having it lit when needed. Of course you can bypass all of this and just get the unlit version I think. But they still need to make a way for the DPI lights to shut off without iCUE on, and without having to use the workaround, which does work fine anyway.From a comfort standpoint, it's also a cut above. In fact, this is probably the most comfortable mouse I have ever used. Everything seems almost perfectly suited to my hands and movements. The mouse itself is quite light but not so that you would get annoyed. It glides extremely well, and there is a calibration setting for glide sensitivity built into iCUE for their better mice. It works, and this is the first time I feel not annoyed by iCUE in ages. It has come a long way, and this mouse makes full use of it.So in reality they have made steps forward in nearly every category here. iCUE is no longer garbage, the mouse functions extremely well, and it is a massive cut above their cheaper options.That about sums it up honestly. Much improved in just about every way. The click area is the same hard plastic with coating that will probably wear away after a year or two of solid use. So keep that in mind as well. These don't last forever. Happy gaming.
